Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Re-developing Puerto Rico's Electric System for Infrastructure Integrity

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Puerto Rico (PR) faces ongoing threats from hurricanes and earthquakes, and needs power infrastructure able to withstand and recover from such events. This capability is defined as Infrastructure integrity (II): the ability of infrastructure to be reliable (maintain service availability), flexible (respond quickly to changes in demand), resilient (use operational measures to minimize service cost impact for recovery from extreme events), and adaptable (invest to adapt infrastructure to changing futures to provide continuous low-cost services).

PR is an extreme example of the choices facing utilities, either because of natural disasters, or because aging infrastructure, energy markets and distribution smart grid opportunities present utilities with more (and possibly conflicting) choices for capital investments in transmission, distribution, central or distributed generation, as well as smart grid operation.

The project has four stages over one year to: 1) Identify main threats to providing continuous, low-cost electric energy services in PR and the primary impediments to restoring electric energy services following occurrence of such events; 2) provide five visions for enhancement of infrastructure integrity, and identify strengths and weaknesses of each; 3) critique and revise the visions based on industry panel debates on strengths and weaknesses of each vision; 4) simulate the economics, infrastructure integrity and environmental sustainability of each vision. The final report will summarize the work and provide a recommendation to move forward with one or a combination of the visions.

The project's strength comes from 1) our team's previous peer-reviewed work simulating infrastructure improvements for greater integrity on behalf of large utilities in the continental US; 2) our experts-- research professors, utilities from all sectors, and consulting engineers, in PR and in the continental US, with long experience in generation, transmission, distribution, and load-side infrastructure investment, all of whom study and confront choices in investment to satisfy Infrastructure Integrity; 3) development of an in-depth "on-the-ground" study of a catastrophic impact on electric systems infrastructure and innovative approaches to enhance infrastructure integrity for future such events.

The development and vetting of this vision can be replicated for other utilities at different scales, providing a roadmap for infrastructure investment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was motivated by the unprecedented destruction of the electric infrastructure in Puerto Rico by the 2017 Hurricane Maria and the likelihood of increased frequency that Puerto Rico will see similar hurricanes in the future. The objective of this project was to identify portfolios of electric infrastructure investment that would minimize the 20-year total cost of electric infrastructure investment plus the cost of operating the electric system to satisfy the Puerto Rican electric demand during times of normal conditions as well as hurricane conditions. This objective was achieved by developing a computerized modeling system called GTD-P4R (Generation-Transmission-Distribution Planning For Resilience) together with a dataset characterizing the existing Puerto Rican electric system. The dataset also characterized future investment options in terms of location, timing, technology, and capacity (amount).

Unlike infrastructure planning methods of the past, the investment options included considered by the GTD-P4R modeling system included two fundamentally different types: investment options for increasing generation, transmission, or distribution capacity to minimize costs under normal (non-hurricane) conditions, and investment options for enhancing the resilience to failure of generation, transmission, or distribution facilities under hurricane conditions. GTD-P4R, then, looks out over a 20 year period (which includes both normal and hurricane conditions) and identifies the portfolio of capacity investments and resilience investments that minimize the cost of those investments plus the cost of operating the system during both types of conditions in that 20 year period. The resulting integration of capacity and resilience investments are considered to be the "best" (optimal) combination of such investments in order to achieve cost minimization and resilience maximization. 

We applied the GTD-P4R modeling system to the Puerto Rican dataset to explore the performance of five different visions of infrastructure investment portfolios.  There were two substantive conclusions that resulted from developing and studying these five visions. First, adding distributed generation (generation connected at the lower voltage distribution system, which is close to the load centers) is generally an effective and economically attractive way to provide electric energy during normal conditions while increasing resilience during hurricane events. Second, distributed generation can be used to displace centralized generation while increasing resilience, but only up to a point. Too much reduction of centralized generation can result in degrading resilience. This means that GTD-P4R does its job very well by not only balancing capacity investment against resilience investment but also by balancing distributed investment against centralized investment. 

We expect GTD-P4R to be directly applicable for planning power systems along the Eastern and Gulf coasts of mainland US where hurricane frequency is similar to that of Puerto Rico. In addition, the GTD-P4R modeling system is generalizable so that it can also identify tradeoffs between capacity and resilience investments, and between distributed and centralized investments, for other types of extreme events as well, e.g., wildfires, floods, earthquakes, tornados, and tsunamis. Thus, we expect GTD-P4R to be applicable to planning most power systems in the US. This will become more and more important as global warming causes the frequency of many of these kinds of events to increase.
